item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "Pirates could happen to anyone." -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Bill Watterson
item.description: "You know, Hobbes, some days even my lucky rocket ship underpants don't help." -- Bill Watterson

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Ian McEwan
item.description: "A story was a form of telepathy. By means of inking symbols onto a page, she was able to send thoughts and feelings from her mind to her reader's. It was a magical process, so commonplace that no one stopped to wonder at it." -- Ian McEwan

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "We're actors — we're the opposite of people!" -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "It makes me so happy. To be at the beginning again, knowing almost nothing.... A door like this has cracked open five or six times since we got up on our hind legs. It's the best possible time of being alive, when almost everything you thought you knew is wrong." -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "Rosencrantz: I don't believe in it anyway. Guildenstern: What? Rosencrantz: England. Guildenstern: Just a conspiracy of cartographers, then? " -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "They loved, and quarreled, and made up, and loved, and fought, and were true to each other and untrue. She made him the happiest man in the whole world and the most wretched, and after a few years she died, and then, when he was thirty, he died, too. But by that time Catullus had invented the love poem." -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "It's not the voting that's democracy, it's the counting." -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "For most of history, Anonymous was a woman." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "There was a boy called Eustace Clarence Scrubb, and he almost deserved it." -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Susan Cooper
item.description: "For Drake is no longer in his hammock, children, nor is Arthur somewhere sleeping, and you may not lie idly expecting the second coming of anybody now, because the world is yours and it is up to you." -- Susan Cooper

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I do not want people to be very agreeable, as it saves me the trouble of liking them a great deal." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "To lose one parent may be regarded as a misfortune; to lose both looks like carelessness." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "I do not approve of anything that tampers with natural ignorance. Ignorance is like a delicate exotic fruit; touch it and the bloom is gone. The whole theory of modern education is radically unsound. Fortunately in England, at any rate, education produces no effect whatsoever." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "If I am occasionally a little over-dressed, I make up for it by being always immensely over-educated." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Full fathom five thy father lies; Of his bones are coral made; Those are pearls that were his eyes: Nothing of him that doth fade, But doth suffer a sea-change Into something rich and strange. Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell: Ding-dong Hark! now I hear them,—Ding-dong, bell." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "Now produce your explanation and pray make it improbable." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Now I will believe that there are unicorns..." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Tom Stoppard
item.description: "We cross our bridges when we come to them and burn them behind us, with nothing to show for our progress except a memory of the smell of smoke, and a presumption that once our eyes watered." -- Tom Stoppard

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Your tale, sir, would cure deafness." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by David Mamet
item.description: "As you all know first prize is a Cadillac El Dorado. Anyone wanna see second prize? Second prize is a set of steak knives. Third prize is you're fired." -- David Mamet

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Eugene O'Neill
item.description: "It was a great mistake, my being born a man, I would have been much more successful as a seagull or a fish. As it is, I will always be a stranger who never feels at home, who does not really want and is not really wanted, who can never belong, who must be a little in love with death!" -- Eugene O'Neill

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Anne Carson (Translator)
item.description: "Why does tragedy exist? Because you are full of rage. Why are you full of rage? Because you are full of grief." -- Anne Carson (Translator)

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Penelope Scambly Schott
item.description: "Sometimes the opposite of loss is loss." -- Penelope Scambly Schott

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Cokie Roberts Steve Roberts
item.description: "When kids made a decision for themselves they have a vested interest in showing they were right. Lee wanted to prove to me that he had made the right choice so he worked hard and did well. If we'd forced him to go to college somewhere else all the incentives would've been different. Then he would have had a motive to prove that we were wrong." -- Cokie Roberts Steve Roberts

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Barry Gehm
item.description: "Any technology distinguishable from magic is insufficiently advanced." -- Barry Gehm

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Eleanor Brown
item.description: "She remembered one of her boyfriends asking, offhandedly, how many books she read in a year. "A few hundred," she said. "How do you have the time?" he asked, gobsmacked. She narrowed her eyes and considered the array of potential answers in front of her. Because I don't spend hours flipping through cable complaining there's nothing on? Because my entire Sunday is not eaten up with pre-game, in-game, and post-game talking heads? Because I do not spend every night drinking overpriced beer and engaging in dick-swinging contests with the other financirati? Because when I am waiting in line, at the gym, on the train, eating lunch, I am not complaining about the wait/staring into space/admiring myself in reflective surfaces? I am reading! "I don't know," she said, shrugging." -- Eleanor Brown

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Bill Watterson
item.description: "Reality continues to ruin my life." -- Bill Watterson

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Joanna Russ
item.description: "As my mother once said: The boys throw stones at the frog in jest. But the frogs die in earnest." -- Joanna Russ

item.title: Elizabeth add a quote by Joanna Russ
item.description: "There are plenty of images of women in science fiction. There are hardly any women." -- Joanna Russ
